content: How can I help you today?

I’m not really sure where to start. My wife pushed me to come here, and honestly, I’m feeling skeptical that this will help. Things at home feel like they’re falling apart, and I don’t know what to do anymore.

It sounds like you're carrying a lot right now, and it's not easy to be here when you're feeling unsure. Thank you for sharing that, even though it might be hard to talk about. What would you say is making things at home feel so overwhelming?

It’s mainly my younger son. He’s been acting out a lot, and we just can’t seem to figure out how to help him. My wife and I are arguing more because of it, and I feel like I’m failing as a parent and as a husband. It’s just a lot all at once.

It sounds like you're feeling a lot of pressure, trying to support your son while also navigating the stress it's creating in your relationship with your wife. That sense of worry and feeling like you're not doing enough has been weighing on you. What do you think would help you feel more grounded amidst everything going on?

I don’t even know anymore. I want to help my son, but it’s like nothing we’re doing is working. And I feel so disconnected from my wife—the arguments just make it worse. I guess I wish I could just find some way to fix all of this, but I don’t even know where to start.

It sounds like you're yearning for a solution, yet feeling stuck and unsure of how to begin repairing what's happening with your son and your wife. That feeling of being disconnected and struggling to see progress can make things feel overwhelming. What gives you hope, even a small hope, that improvement might be possible—either for your son, your relationship, or for yourself?
I guess the hope comes from wanting to keep my family together. Even with all the arguments and stress, I don’t want to give up on them. I just wish I knew what to do to make things better.

That desire to keep your family together shows how deeply you care for your wife and son, even in the middle of all this difficulty. Holding onto that hope and commitment is a powerful step. What do you feel you need, personally or as a family, to begin moving toward better times?

I honestly think we just need help—someone to guide us. It's like no matter what we try, we’re just going in circles. But I’m also hesitant because I don’t even know if someone else could really help.

It takes a lot of honesty to admit that asking for help might be necessary, even when you're unsure if it will make a difference. That hesitance is natural—it’s hard to trust the unknown or step into something unfamiliar, especially when it feels like nothing has worked so far. What kind of help would you imagine might be most useful to your family right now?

Maybe working with someone who understands kids or families, who could help us figure out how to support my son better and maybe help my wife and me communicate without fighting so much. But, honestly, it also feels overwhelming to even think about finding the right person to help.

That makes sense. Wanting someone who understands and can offer guidance for your family is a good idea, but the process of finding that support can feel like just one more thing to manage. Acknowledging how overwhelming that feels shows you're already striving to think things through. What would make it feel less daunting for you to take that first step toward finding someone?

Maybe if someone could give a recommendation, or if my wife and I could work together on finding the right person, it wouldn’t feel like I’m carrying it all alone. It’s just hard to know where to begin, and I don’t want to get it wrong.

Recognizing that it could feel more manageable with support—whether through a recommendation or working alongside your wife—shows a lot of thoughtfulness. You don’t want to make the wrong choice, because this is important to you and your family. What do you think about having a conversation with your wife about exploring options together? It could be a way to share the weight and strengthen your connection in the process.
I think a conversation with her could be a good idea. Maybe we could figure out how to work together on this instead of it feeling like we're on opposite sides all the time. It's worth a try.

That willingness to have a conversation and work as a team is a strong step forward. It shows how much you value your relationship and want to create solutions together. Is there anything else you’d like to explore or talk through before moving toward that conversation with your wife?
I think I’m okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
